subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] I need clarification on British pronunciations.
msgSnippet: Thank you for the information. You said that there is no pronounced r in Read s accent. If that is the case, why did he consistently use letter 25 (alone
messageBody:
Thank you for the information. 
You said that there is no pronounced "r" in Read's accent. If that is the case, why did he consistently use letter 25 (alone and combined with vowels) in his manual? 
Yes, as far as my ears can tell, here "hole" and "hull", and "whole" for that manner are identical in their pronunciation. If you added a "D", all three would sound like "hold".
32 & 34 are still throwing me for a loop. Even in the site you referenced the same vowel is used for "not" and "calm", which you mentioned should be spelled with 32 and 34. Using the following link as a common ground, can you use the IPA letters to help me understand the difference between the two? http://web.uvic.ca/ling/resources/ipa/charts/IPAlab/IPAlab.htm
The fact that that there is no satisfactory combination for the butter still bugs me. Using # 25 as a vowel sounds like a good idea, but it doesn't work if that sound is at the beginning of the word.  I just wish there was a better option. 

Thank you for your help!



On Tuesday, February 17, 2015 9:57 AM, "cowan@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


 
my_socks_smell scripsit:

> (I have the accent which is used by
> the majority of Americans; the same that is used in almost every American
> movie).

Actually, there is no majority American accent. You sound like you have
a California/Southwestern accent.

> If I could hear recordings of Read's voice,

The accent Read is working with is called "conservative RP". Googling
that phraes should turn up plenty of samples. Read's alphabets do make
one major concession to American (and Canadian, Scottish, Irish, and
West Country) accents: there is a representation of "r" after vowels,
even though it is not pronounced in RP.

> 1. Letter # 26 It
> Initially, I thought this letter makes the sound Americans use in such
> words as igloo, him, spirit.

That's right. Note that some people say "speerit" for "spirit",
but this does not matter, because there is never a contrast between
a word in "ir" (not pronounced "urr") and another word in "eer".

> He uses letter 26 (by the
> way, if these letters have accepted names, I would love to know)

Names appear on the chart.

> busy

I've never heard anyone say "beezy" rather than "bizzy" for this word.
It has the same "ih" sound as the examples you give above.

> Mary

This is not a US/UK difference, but an older/younger difference.
Until about 1950, final "-y" was pronounced "ih" on both sides
of the Atlantic and elsewhere. This has now mostly changed to "ee",
at different rates in different places. If you can find a clip
of former President Jimmy Carter saying his name, you'll hear
that he says "Jimmy" with the same vowel in both syllables: Jih-mih.
Read naturally used the older "ih" sound. It makes no difference
to any word, so you can use what you like.

> writing

I'll talk about "ng" later.

> 2. Letters # 32 Ah, #33 Awe, #34 Ox
> At first, I could make no distinction between these three, but now I do
> believe I can tell a slight difference in 33.

About half the English speakers in the world distinguish between
#32 and #33. The exceptions are the American Midwest and West, and
Canada. You can hear the distinction in the non-words "Ahhhhh!",
meaning satisfaction, which is #32, and "Awwwww!", meaning pity or
sympathy, which is #33. I for example have a sharp distinction
as a Northeasterner, and so do people on the U.S. side of the
Great Lakes and in the South.

> I am still at a loss to
> hear any difference at all between 32 and 34.

Almost nobody in North America makes this distinction except in
Boston and Eastern New England, where #33 = #34 but #32 is separate.
But the rest of the world does. In particular, in RP (Read's accent),
#32 and #33 and #34 are all quite distinct.

> words like cough, not, calm?

As it happens, "cough" is #33, "not" is #34, "calm" is #32.
You can use an online British/American dictionary like
<http://www.oxforddictionaries.com> to learn the differences,
which mostly correlate pretty well with Orthodox spelling.
Change the drop-down at the left end of the site search
to "British and World English". The pronunciation shown is
IPA, which you can learn in various places on the Web, but
since you only care about the differences, not the exact
pronunciations, you can figure it out for yourself by
looking up the three words above.

> Does 33 make the sound which Americans say
> in "The Titanic got a hole in her hull, as she pulled away from the
> iceburg"?

I'm not sure if you mean that you pronounce "hole" and "hull" the same
or not. In any case, "hole" and "hull" are written differently in
Read alphabets, using #17 and #23 respectively.

> 3. Letters #21 Ing
> For the life of me, I can't figure out this letter! At first I thought it
> made the full "ing" sound (Americans pronounce this like eeeeeng, with an
> audible g),

This is a matter not of failing to pronounce the sound, but failing
to recognize it. Most people don't pronounce "sing" as "sing-g":
exceptions are Birmingham, England, and Long Island, N.Y, where the
local pronunciations are "Birming-gum" and "Long Guyland". And
except in those few places, "singer" and "finger" don't rhyme:
the former is "sing-er", the latter is "fing-ger". Now "sing"
is not pronounced like "sin" either, so it needs a separate
Read letter. We write "sing" as #11 #26 #21, "singer" as
#11 #26 #21 #36 #25, and "finger" as #9 #26 #21 #6 #36 #25.
Note the #6 in "finger" that isn't found in "singer".

(Technically, #23 is an alveolar nasal, pronounced in the same
part of the mouth as "t" or "d", whereas #21 is a velar nasal,
pronounced in the same part of the mouth as "k" or "g".)

> The only pattern I can find with this letter is that it
> is always followed by the G or K sound;

Definitely not, as shown above: words ending in "ng", like
"long", use #21 alone.

> I am able to write all the words with the letter # 23
> instead, and it works perfectly.

If you wrote "tango" with #23 #6 instead of #21 #6, I would read it
as "tan go", as in "If you want a tan, go to the Caribbean."

To take up the question of the pronunciation of the vowel "i" before
"ng" from above: Most people use #26 for this, but Southwesterners
tend to use #27. It doesn't much matter, because once again there
are no words which distinguish between #26 #21 and #27 #21. This
is again different from #23: "kin" and "keen" are not the same.

> 4. Combination letters
> The letter # 25 Roe combines with several of the vowels, and my accent
> agrees with half of the combos. With an American accent, the word "air"
> should be written 28-25 instead of the given 29-25. Read writes the word
> "marry" with 30-25, which combo isn't used with my accent.

Right, you pronounce "marry", "merry", and "Mary" all alike. But
Easterners don't, and neither do people outside North America, and
Southerners usually merge "merry" and "Mary" but distinguish
"marry". To me, when you say any of these words, it sounds like
you are saying "Mary", i.e. #29 #25. For me, "merry" is #28 #25
and "marry" is #30 25. Orthodox spelling is a good guide here.

> If I
> understand the correct pronunciation of letter 36 Utter, then the combo
> of 36-25 is not correct in words such as butter, early, girl, murder.
> When the two letters are pronounced individually in quick succession, it
> does not make the necessary sound for the above words, with my accent.

Yes, that's a known deficiency in Quikscript, and you just have to get
used to #36 #25.

> 36-25 comes close, as well as 39-25, but neither do the job properly. I
> think this sound needs a completely new letter; I just use the letter 25
> turned backwards to signify this sound in my own writing.

An alternative is to just use #25 as a vowel. If you say "curd",
for example, there are really just three sounds in it: #6 #25 #4.

> Also, I believe that letters 35 OY, and 37 OUt
> are simply combination sound as well, and are perhaps unnecessary letters
> as a result. I think that #35 is a combo of 33 & 17.

It could be written so, yes. For that matter, #31 (the sound of
"price") could be written #32 #17. But anglophones think of #31
as a unitary vowel, and Read catered to this understanding.
The convention as given means that #17 and #18 appear only at
the beginning of a syllable.

I hope this is helpful.

--
John Cowan http://www.ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
Not to perambulate the corridors during the hours of repose
in the boots of ascension. --Sign in Austrian ski-resort hotel

<html><body><div style=3D"color:#000; background-color:#fff; font-family:He=
lveticaNeue, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, Lucida Grande, sans-serif;fo=
nt-size:16px"><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_48470"><spa=
n id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_49702">Thank you for the information.&nb=
sp;</span></div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_46332"><s=
pan id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_46509">You said that there is no prono=
unced "r" in Read's accent. If that is the case, why did he consistently us=
e letter 25 (alone and combined with vowels) in his manual? </span></d=
iv><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_43112"><span id=3D"yui=
_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_43114">Yes, as far as my ears can tell, here "hole"=
 and "hull", and "whole" for that manner are identical in their pronunciati=
on. If you added a "D", all three would sound like "hold".</span></div><div=
 dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_43112"><span id=3D"yui_3_16_0=
_1_1424469810921_47769">32 & 34 are still throwing me for a loop. Even =
in the site you referenced the same vowel is used for "not" and "calm", whi=
ch you mentioned should be spelled with 32 and 34. Using the following link=
 as a common ground, can you use the IPA letters to help me understand the =
difference between the two? <a href=3D"http://web.uvic.ca/ling/resourc=
es/ipa/charts/IPAlab/IPAlab.htm" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_50562">ht=
tp://web.uvic.ca/ling/resources/ipa/charts/IPAlab/IPAlab.htm</a></span></di=
v><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_43112">The fact that th=
at there is no satisfactory combination for the butt<b style=3D"text-decora=
tion: underline;">er</b> still bugs me. Using # 25 as a vowel sounds l=
ike a good idea, but it doesn't work if that sound is at the beginning of t=
he word.  I just wish there was a better option.<font face=3D"Georgia"=
><span style=3D"font-size: 13px; line-height: 15.8599996566772px;"> </=
span></font></div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_43112">=
<font face=3D"Georgia"><span style=3D"font-size: 13px; line-height: 15.8599=
996566772px;"><br></span></font></div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1=
424469810921_43112"><font face=3D"Georgia"><span style=3D"font-size: 13px; =
line-height: 15.8599996566772px;">Thank you for your help!</span></font></d=
iv><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yui_3_16_0_1_1424469810921_43112"><br></div> <div=
 class=3D"qtdSeparateBR"><br><br></div><div class=3D"yahoo_quoted" style=3D=
"display: block;"> <div style=3D"font-family: HelveticaNeue, Helvetica Neue=
, Helvetica, Arial, Lucida Grande, sans-serif; font-size: 16px;"> <div styl=
e=3D"font-family: HelveticaNeue, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, Lucida G=
rande, sans-serif; font-size: 16px;"> <div dir=3D"ltr"> <font size=3D"2" fa=
ce=3D"Arial"> On Tuesday, February 17, 2015 9:57 AM, "cowan@... [Read_=
Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:<br> </font> </div> =
 <br><br> <div class=3D"y_msg_container"><div id=3D"yiv3655120750"><div>
<s=
pan style=3D"display:none;"> </span>

mlmsg" style=3D"">

    =
<div id=3D"yiv3655120750ygrp-text">


      <div>my_socks_smell scripsit:<b=
r clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
> (I have the accent which is used=
 by<br clear=3D"none">
> the majority of Americans; the same that is use=
d in almost every American<br clear=3D"none">
> movie).<br clear=3D"none=
">
<br clear=3D"none">
Actually, there is no majority American accent.  You=
 sound like you have<br clear=3D"none">
a California/Southwestern accent.<b=
r clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
> If I could hear recordings of Re=
ad's voice,<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
The accent Read is worki=
ng with is called "conservative RP".  Googling<br clear=3D"none">
that phra=
es should turn up plenty of samples.  Read's alphabets do make<br clear=3D"=
none">
one major concession to American (and Canadian, Scottish, Irish, and=
<br clear=3D"none">
West Country) accents: there is a representation of "r"=
 after vowels,<br clear=3D"none">
even though it is not pronounced in RP.<b=
r clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
>  1. Letter # 26 It<br clear=3D"n=
one">
>  Initially, I thought this letter makes the sound Americans use =
in such<br clear=3D"none">
> words as igloo, him, spirit.<br clear=3D"no=
ne">
<br clear=3D"none">
That's right.  Note that some people say "speerit"=
 for "spirit",<br clear=3D"none">
but this does not matter, because there i=
s never a contrast between<br clear=3D"none">
a word in "ir" (not pronounce=
d "urr") and another word in "eer".<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
=
> He uses letter 26 (by the<br clear=3D"none">
> way, if these letter=
s have accepted names, I would love to know)<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=
=3D"none">
Names appear on the chart.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none"=
>
> busy<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
I've never heard anyone =
say "beezy" rather than "bizzy" for this word.<br clear=3D"none">
It has th=
e same "ih" sound as the examples you give above.<br clear=3D"none">
<br cl=
ear=3D"none">
> Mary<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
This is not =
a US/UK difference, but an older/younger difference.<br clear=3D"none">
Unt=
il about 1950, final "-y" was pronounced "ih" on both sides<br clear=3D"non=
e">
of the Atlantic and elsewhere.  This has now mostly changed to "ee",<br=
 clear=3D"none">
at different rates in different places.  If you can find a=
 clip<br clear=3D"none">
of former President Jimmy Carter saying his name, =
you'll hear<br clear=3D"none">
that he says "Jimmy" with the same vowel in =
both syllables: Jih-mih.<br clear=3D"none">
Read naturally used the older "=
ih" sound.  It makes no difference<br clear=3D"none">
to any word, so you c=
an use what you like.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
> writing<b=
r clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
I'll talk about "ng" later.<br clear=
=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
>  2. Letters # 32 Ah, #33 Awe, #34 Ox<br=
 clear=3D"none">
>  At first, I could make no distinction between these =
three, but now I do<br clear=3D"none">
> believe I can tell a slight dif=
ference in 33.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
About half the Englis=
h speakers in the world distinguish between<br clear=3D"none">
#32 and #33.=
  The exceptions are the American Midwest and West, and<br clear=3D"none">
=
Canada.  You can hear the distinction in the non-words "Ahhhhh!",<br clear=
=3D"none">
meaning satisfaction, which is #32, and "Awwwww!", meaning pity =
or<br clear=3D"none">
sympathy, which is #33.  I for example have a sharp d=
istinction<br clear=3D"none">
as a Northeasterner, and so do people on the =
U.S. side of the<br clear=3D"none">
Great Lakes and in the South.<br clear=
=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
> I am still at a loss to<br clear=3D"non=
e">
> hear any difference at all between 32 and 34.<br clear=3D"none">
<=
br clear=3D"none">
Almost nobody in North America makes this distinction ex=
cept in<br clear=3D"none">
Boston and Eastern New England, where #33 =3D #3=
4 but #32 is separate.<br clear=3D"none">
But the rest of the world does.  =
In particular, in RP (Read's accent),<br clear=3D"none">
#32 and #33 and #3=
4 are all quite distinct.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
> words=
 like cough, not, calm?<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
As it happen=
s, "cough" is #33, "not" is #34, "calm" is #32.<br clear=3D"none">
You can =
use an online British/American dictionary like<br clear=3D"none">
<http:=
//www.oxforddictionaries.com> to learn the differences,<br clear=3D"none=
">
which mostly correlate pretty well with Orthodox spelling.<br clear=3D"n=
one">
Change the drop-down at the left end of the site search<br clear=3D"n=
one">
to "British and World English".  The pronunciation shown is<br clear=
=3D"none">
IPA, which you can learn in various places on the Web, but<br cl=
ear=3D"none">
since you only care about the differences, not the exact<br c=
lear=3D"none">
pronunciations, you can figure it out for yourself by<br cle=
ar=3D"none">
looking up the three words above.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=
=3D"none">
> Does 33 make the sound which Americans say<br clear=3D"none=
">
> in "The Titanic got a hole in her hull, as she pulled away from the=
<br clear=3D"none">
> iceburg"?<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
I=
'm not sure if you mean that you pronounce "hole" and "hull" the same<br cl=
ear=3D"none">
or not.  In any case, "hole" and "hull" are written different=
ly in<br clear=3D"none">
Read alphabets, using #17 and #23 respectively.<br=
 clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
>  3. Letters #21 Ing<br clear=3D"n=
one">
>  For the life of me, I can't figure out this letter! At first I =
thought it<br clear=3D"none">
> made the full "ing" sound (Americans pro=
nounce this like eeeeeng, with an<br clear=3D"none">
> audible g),<br cl=
ear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
This is a matter not of failing to pronou=
nce the sound, but failing<br clear=3D"none">
to recognize it.  Most people=
 don't pronounce "sing" as "sing-g":<br clear=3D"none">
exceptions are Birm=
ingham, England, and Long Island, N.Y, where the<br clear=3D"none">

local =
pronunciations are "Birming-gum" and "Long Guyland".  And<br clear=3D"none"=
>
except in those few places, "singer" and "finger" don't rhyme:<br clear=
=3D"none">
the former is "sing-er", the latter is "fing-ger".  Now "sing"<b=
r clear=3D"none">
is not pronounced like "sin" either, so it needs a separa=
te<br clear=3D"none">
Read letter.  We write "sing" as #11 #26 #21, "singer=
" as<br clear=3D"none">
#11 #26 #21 #36 #25, and "finger" as #9 #26 #21 #6 =
#36 #25.<br clear=3D"none">
Note the #6 in "finger" that isn't found in "si=
nger".<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
(Technically, #23 is an alveo=
lar nasal, pronounced in the same<br clear=3D"none">
part of the mouth as "=
t" or "d", whereas #21 is a velar nasal,<br clear=3D"none">
pronounced in t=
he same part of the mouth as "k" or "g".)<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"n=
one">
> The only pattern I can find with this letter is that it<br clear=
=3D"none">
> is always followed by the G or K sound;<br clear=3D"none">
=
<br clear=3D"none">
Definitely not, as shown above:  words ending in "ng", =
like<br clear=3D"none">
"long", use #21 alone.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=
=3D"none">
> I am able to write all the words with the letter # 23<br cl=
ear=3D"none">
> instead, and it works perfectly.<br clear=3D"none">
<br =
clear=3D"none">
If you wrote "tango" with #23 #6 instead of #21 #6, I would=
 read it<br clear=3D"none">
as "tan go", as in "If you want a tan, go to th=
e Caribbean."<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
To take up the questio=
n of the pronunciation of the vowel "i" before<br clear=3D"none">
"ng" from=
 above:  Most people use #26 for this, but Southwesterners<br clear=3D"none=
">
tend to use #27.  It doesn't much matter, because once again there<br cl=
ear=3D"none">
are no words which distinguish between #26 #21 and #27 #21.  =
This<br clear=3D"none">
is again different from #23:  "kin" and "keen" are =
not the same.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
>  4. Combination l=
etters<br clear=3D"none">
>  The letter # 25 Roe combines with several o=
f the vowels, and my accent<br clear=3D"none">
> agrees with half of the=
 combos. With an American accent, the word "air"<br clear=3D"none">

> s=
hould be written 28-25 instead of the given 29-25. Read writes the word<br =
clear=3D"none">
> "marry" with 30-25, which combo isn't used with my acc=
ent.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
Right, you pronounce "marry", "=
merry", and "Mary" all alike.  But<br clear=3D"none">
Easterners don't, and=
 neither do people outside North America, and<br clear=3D"none">
Southerner=
s usually merge "merry" and "Mary" but distinguish<br clear=3D"none">
"marr=
y".  To me, when you say any of these words, it sounds like<br clear=3D"non=
e">
you are saying "Mary", i.e. #29 #25.  For me, "merry" is #28 #25<br cle=
ar=3D"none">
and "marry" is #30 25.  Orthodox spelling is a good guide here=
.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
> If I<br clear=3D"none">
> =
understand the correct pronunciation of letter 36 Utter, then the combo<br =
clear=3D"none">
> of 36-25 is not correct in words such as butter, early=
, girl, murder.<br clear=3D"none">
> When the two letters are pronounced=
 individually in quick succession, it<br clear=3D"none">
> does not make=
 the necessary sound for the above words, with my accent.<br clear=3D"none"=
>
<br clear=3D"none">
Yes, that's a known deficiency in Quikscript, and you=
 just have to get<br clear=3D"none">
used to #36 #25.<br clear=3D"none">
<b=
r clear=3D"none">
> 36-25 comes close, as well as 39-25, but neither do =
the job properly. I<br clear=3D"none">
> think this sound needs a comple=
tely new letter; I just use the letter 25<br clear=3D"none">
> turned ba=
ckwards to signify this sound in my own writing.<br clear=3D"none">
<br cle=
ar=3D"none">
An alternative is to just use #25 as a vowel.  If you say "cur=
d",<br clear=3D"none">
for example, there are really just three sounds in i=
t:  #6 #25 #4.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
> Also, I believe =
that letters 35 OY, and 37 OUt<br clear=3D"none">
> are simply combinati=
on sound as well, and are perhaps unnecessary letters<br clear=3D"none">
&g=
t; as a result. I think that #35 is a combo of 33 & 17.<br clear=3D"non=
e">
<br clear=3D"none">
It could be written so, yes.  For that matter, #31 =
(the sound of<br clear=3D"none">
"price") could be written #32 #17.  But an=
glophones think of #31<br clear=3D"none">
as a unitary vowel, and Read cate=
red to this understanding.<br clear=3D"none">
The convention as given means=
 that #17 and #18 appear only at<br clear=3D"none">
the beginning of a syll=
able.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
I hope this is helpful.<br cle=
ar=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
-- <br clear=3D"none">
John Cowan         =
 http://www.ccil.org/~cowan        cowan@...<br clear=3D"none">
Not to=
 perambulate the corridors during the hours of repose<br clear=3D"none">
in=
 the boots of ascension.       --Sign in Austrian ski-resort hotel<br clear=
=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
</div>
